PT J
AU Vallor, S
AF Vallor, Shannon
TI An enactive-phenomenological approach to veridical perception
SO JOURNAL OF CONSCIOUSNESS STUDIES
LA English
DT Article
ID CHANGE-BLINDNESS; VISION; IDENTIFICATION; CONSCIOUSNESS; ATTENTION
AB Most accounts of veridical perception draw upon conventional causal theories of perception for an explanatory framework. Recently developed enactive or sensorimotor theories of perception pose a challenge to such accounts, necessitating a redefinition of veridical perception. I propose and defend one such definition, drawing upon empirical studies of perception, the resources of the enactive approach and phenomenology. I argue that perceptual experience engages an organism in a network of sensorimotor dependencies with the perceived object, and that veridical perceptions. involve experiential mastery of these dependencies. A thought example involving the phoneme restoration effect is used to compare this definition favourably with traditional accounts of veridical perception that involve the generation of matching content with appropriate causal history or patterns of counterfactual dependence. I also defend my account of veridical perception against several objections.
C1 Santa Clara Univ, Dept Philosophy, Santa Clara, CA 95053 USA.
RP Vallor, S (reprint author), Santa Clara Univ, Dept Philosophy, 500 Camino Real, Santa Clara, CA 95053 USA.

PT J
AU Brogan, MJ
AF Brogan, Michael J.
TI Science of being, science of faith: Philosophy and theology according to
   Heidegger
SO AMERICAN CATHOLIC PHILOSOPHICAL QUARTERLY
LA English
DT Article
AB This essay is a critical investigation of Heidegger's insistence on the absolute difference between philosophy, defined as fundamental ontology, and theology, understood as the "ontic" "science of faith." Focusing primarily on two important works from 1927, "Phenomenology and Theology" and Being and Time, I argue that the distinction between the two disciplines begins to blur in light of the circular character of hermeneutical understanding as Heidegger himself describes it. Ontology, he concedes, has ontic roots in the authentic self-understanding of Dasein. I maintain that this understanding involves an interpretive decision that, lacking the pure phenomenological rationality Heidegger attributes to it, looks much like the faith he would banish from philosophy.
C1 Villanova Univ, Villanova, PA 19085 USA.
RP Brogan, MJ (reprint author), Villanova Univ, Villanova, PA 19085 USA.

PT J
AU Curzer, HJ
AF Curzer, HJ
TI Admirable immorality, dirty hands, ticking bombs, and torturing
   innocents
SO SOUTHERN JOURNAL OF PHILOSOPHY
LA English
DT Article
ID INTEGRITY
AB Is torturing innocent people ever morally required? I rebut responses to the ticking-bomb dilemma by Slote, Williams, Walzer, and others. I argue that torturing is morally required and should be performed when it is the only way to avert disasters. In such situations, torturers act with dirty hands because torture, though required, is vicious. Conversely, refusers act wrongly, yet virtuously, thus displaying admirable immorality. Vicious, morally required acts and virtuous, morally wrong acts are odd, yet necessary to preserve the ticking-bomb dilemma's phenomenology, the role of habituation in moral development, the virtue/continence distinction, and morality's overridingness, consistency, and plausibility.
C1 Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX 79409 USA.
RP Curzer, HJ (reprint author), Texas Tech Univ, Lubbock, TX 79409 USA.

PT J
AU Davis, C
AF Davis, Colin
TI Levinas and the phenomenology of reading
SO STUDIA PHAENOMENOLOGICA
LA English
DT Article
AB Although Levinas showed relatively little interest in secular literature, and indeed he was sometimes distinctly hostile towards it, some of his essays sketch a phenomenological account of the reading experience which is applicable to non-sacred texts. This article compares Levinas's phenomenology of reading to that of Wolfgang Iser, and argues that it may be susceptible to some of the same criticisms. It then examines Levinas's 1947 essay "L'Autre dans Proust" in the light of Proust's Un amour de Swann, suggesting that Levinas's reading is blind to aspects of Proust's writing which contradict his ethics. This finally raises questions about the viability of a genuinely enlightening, ethical encounter between reader and text, or between self and other.
C1 Univ London, London WC1E 7HU, England.
RP Davis, C (reprint author), Univ London, London WC1E 7HU, England.

PT J
AU Jacquette, D
AF Jacquette, D
TI Intention, meaning, and substance in the phenomenology of abstract
   painting
SO BRITISH JOURNAL OF AESTHETICS
LA English
DT Article
ID STEIN,GERTRUDE
AB Trying to make sense of abstract painting has resulted in interesting but often inexact and inadequately motivated efforts to characterize what is distinctive about modern art. The present account begins with Gertrude Stein's description of the fascination she experiences in viewing painted surfaces and proceeds through a number of efforts to justify or severely criticize abstract painting in relation to more traditional representational works. The basis for a phenomenology of abstract painting is suggested by James Elkins's first-person analysis of the reasons why painters paint, focusing on the production rather than exclusively on the appreciation of paintings. Elkins's proposal that painters paint as an exploration of the possibilities of working with the material substance of paint is advanced as the basis for a new approach to the problems of understanding the nature of abstract art as the most pure and concentrated form of this remarkable aesthetic preoccupation that is to be found in all paintings and by extension in all art.

PT J
AU Russon, J
AF Russon, John
TI Reading: Derrida in Hegel's understanding (Jacques Derrida)
SO RESEARCH IN PHENOMENOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
AB Hegel's dialectic "Consciousness," Part A from the Phenomenology of Spirit, is interpreted in light of the concept of "reading." The logic of reading is especially helpful for interpreting the often misunderstood dialectic of understanding, as that is described in chapter 3 of the Phenomenology, "Force and Understanding: Appearance and the Supersensible World." Hegel's concept of "the Inverted World" in particular is clarifted, and from it Hegel's notion of originary difference is developed. Derrida's notion of " iffelance" is used to illuminate Hegel's use of difference and to interpret the Hegelian metaphysics that is developed in "Force and Understanding" and in the opening moves of Hegel's Science of Logic. It is argued that the philosophical projects of Hegel and Derrida are ultimately indistinguishable.
C1 Univ Guelph, Guelph, ON N1G 2W1, Canada.
RP Russon, J (reprint author), Univ Guelph, Guelph, ON N1G 2W1, Canada.

PT B

PT J
AU Kim, A
AF Kim, A
TI Shades of truth: Phenomenological perspectives on the allegory of the
   cave
SO IDEALISTIC STUDIES
LA English
DT Article
AB Plato's allegory of the cave tells of the soul's advance from ignorance to knowledge, leaving open the question of what this knowledge is and what its objects are. Heidegger's 1947 analysis of the allegory is of course just one of many. However, as I argue in this paper, if we read that analysis in the context of Husserlian phenomenology, we find a remarkable congruence between the latter's process of "eidetic reduction" and the ascent out of the cave. In 1, I lay out the phenomenological concepts relevant to my interpretation of Heidegger's text. In 2, I apply these to the allegory itself In 3, I examine Heidegger's critique of eidetic "truth" in the allegory, arguing that it equally applies to Husserl's phenomenology. My paper shows both the utility and limits of a "phenomenological" approach to reading Plato's theory of forms.
C1 Univ Memphis, Memphis, TN 38152 USA.
RP Kim, A (reprint author), Univ Memphis, Memphis, TN 38152 USA.

PT J
AU Vermersch, P
AF Vermersch, P
TI Attention between phenomenology and experimental psychology
SO CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY REVIEW
LA English
DT Article
ID EVERYDAY MEMORY; PERCEPTION
AB It is possible to consider attention as the modulating dimension of consciousness. Understood in this sense, attention can be a privileged theme for relating the first person point of view (conceived as a psycho-phenomenology inspired by the work of Husserl) to the experimental sciences (e.g. psychology, neuropsychology, etc.), which have done a great deal of work on attention. This article will take up in succession some different points of view regarding the status of attention and its structure (e.g. static aspects). It will also consider the dynamic of attention from a micro-genetic point of view as well as a functional point of views. The final section will seek to show not only the unique and original contributions of each perspective, but also each perspective's limitations and biases.
C1 CNRS, GREX, F-43300 St Eble, France.

PT J
AU Angel, L
AF Angel, L
TI Universal self consciousness mysticism and the physical completeness
   principle
SO INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL FOR PHILOSOPHY OF RELIGION
LA English
DT Article
AB Philosophers promoting a version of Universal Self Consciousness mysticism (including Wainwright, Alston, Hick, Wilber and Forman) take it that their interpretations of mysticism are consistent with current scientific findings. However, their theories have been implicitly or explicitly against the central claim arising from science, namely, the physical causal completeness principle. There is strong ground to accept physical causal completeness for human functioning, and the assessment of physical completeness is independent of the phenomenology of Universal Self Consciousness mystical experience. Further, there is a positive account of Universal Self Consciousness mysticism that accepts physical causal completeness. Such an account is preferable to the many accounts that both require its denial and yet give no basically satisfactory evidence to ground that denial.
C1 Douglas Coll, Dept Philosophy & Humanities, New Westminster, BC, Canada.

PT J
AU Stunkel, KM
AF Stunkel, KM
TI Consent - Language according to Hamann and Heidegger (Exploring
   parallels between theology and phenomenology)
SO NEUE ZEITSCHRIFT FUR SYSTEMATISCHE THEOLOGIE UND RELIGIONSPHILOSOPHIE
LA German
DT Article
AB There is more to Johann Georg Hamann's thoughts on language than a mere theory of communication. Although very rarely being compared, there are considerable parallels between the theology of Hamann's thinking of language and the phenomenology of Martin Heidegger. Oswald Bayer's recent commentary on Hamann's metacritical writings provides the opportunity to take a closer look at the neglected relationship between both thinkers. Their major correspondence lies in heir common basic assumption concerning the priority of language ("Sprache") to communication ("Sprechen"). communication originates from an act of condescendence wherein they allow communication and translation due to foundation of the "Word" in the Lutheran structure of "Promissio". The adequate behaviour of both theologian and phenomenologist towards this provocation of sacramental language is to listen and to respond to the founding Word in contrast to scientific investigation by the means of metaphysically based questions. thus the answer ("Antwort") to the arrival of the Word is the freedom of responsible childhood ("mundige Kindschaft") in the obedience and affiliation of the Word.
RP Stunkel, KM (reprint author), Ellersiekstr 40, D-32257 Bunde, Germany.

PT J
AU Dastur, F
AF Dastur, F
TI The "extreme god" of phenomenology. Husserl and Heidegger
SO ARCHIVES DE PHILOSOPHIE
LA French
DT Article
DE phenomenology; theology; the Divine; finitude
AB Husserl knew how to separate phenomenology from Kant's distinction between two modes of initiating reality, a distinction that Hegel united from the perspective of the absolute. The separation established by Husserl allowed him to generalise l'intuitus derivatus and to attribute it to God, thus freeing himself from the task of posing the existence of a being behind the phenomena. Alongside the "long christianization of God" which constitutes the foundation of our tradition, Heidegger, interpreting Holderlin, announces the enigmatic occurrence of the "ultimate God" in the "depths of being" - a being no longer opposed to becoming, but understood from the perspective of its historicity. This god enters into and reveals by his presence this last sign - "the intimate finitude of being".
C1 Univ Nice, F-06108 Nice 2, France.
RP Dastur, F (reprint author), Univ Nice, F-06108 Nice 2, France.
CR DASTUR F, 1994, REV PHILOS LOUVAIN, V92, P226, DOI 10.2143/RPL.92.2.556255

PT J
AU Rabanus, C
AF Rabanus, C
TI The meaning of history in the "heretical essays"
SO FILOSOFICKY CASOPIS
LA Czech
DT Article
AB The essay at hand deals with Jan Patocka's philosophy of history as it is recorded in his Heretical Essays Developing against the background of the problem of the natural world and thus locating Patocka's philosophy between those of Edmund Husserl and Martin Heidegger, this examination will centre around the concept of "history" and of "meaning" and around the problem of the meaning of history. With reference to Patocka's theory of the three movements of human existence and to his dividing history into three epochs, his concept of "history in its actual meaning" shall be explained. In this way it will be found that this concept of history indicates a certain epoch, namely that epoch in the development of human Being in which man has become conscious of his freedom and of his responsibility. The examination of Patocka's concept of meaning then supports the thesis that "meaning" with Patocka is the same as "horizon" in the philosophy of Husserl, that "meaning" is "what makes the understanding of a thing possible". As a consequence, only man's Being can have meaning. This result is afterwards related to Patocka's concept of an a-subjective phenomenology which then opens the question of the origin of "meaning" and finally leads to the question of the Appearing-in-itself The last part of the essay outlines the power and also the limits of Patocka's a-subjective phenomenology.
CR Frege G., 1967, KLEINE SCHRIFTEN, P143
   HEIDEGGER K, 1989, HEIDEGGER PRAKTISCHE, P126
   HEIDEGGER M., 1996, BYTI CAS
   HEIDEGGER M, 1996, SACHE DENKENS, P1
   HUSSERL E, 1966, HUSSERLIANA, V10, P382
   LEWIS D, 1995, PLURALITY WORLDS, pS53
   PATOCKA J., 1969, FILOS CAS, V17, P682
   PATOCKA J, 1988, KETZERISCHE ESSAIS P, P82

   PATOCKA J, 1991, PHANOMENOLOGISCHE SC, V2, P267

PT J
AU KOTATKO, P
AF KOTATKO, P
TI WITTGENSTEIN AND THE CARTESIAN SUBJECT
SO FILOSOFICKY CASOPIS
LA Czech
DT Article
AB The paper deals with two Wittgenstein's arguments concerning the problem of rule-following: the argument against private language (PIA), i.e. language whose expressions refer or apply exclusively to private phenomena, and the argument against individual language (ILA), i.e. language whose semantic rules are introduced and fixed by intentions of on isolated speaker. Part I suggests a way of reconstruction of PLA, while part II characterizes Wittgenstein's account of public discourse about mental states in the light of PLA. Parts III-V discuss ILA, esp. in its Kripkean version, focussing on its consequences for the account of public communication. The idea of the general agreement in communicative practices (based on the shared form of life) and of rule-following as a participation in these practices, is liable to the same kind of scepticism as IL. To be immune, it requires a weaker notion of rules than that exploited in the sceptical part of ILA. ILA (and PLA) is a good introduction to the externalist account of meaning and communication, but is not sufficient to refute internalism. On the other side, ILA und PLA challenge the Cartesian notion of subject as a realm of transparency and absolute evidences: hence they undermine ambitions of philosophical programmes like Husserl's transcendental phenomenology, independently on whether these presuppose the possibility of IL (PL) or not (part VIII).
RP KOTATKO, P (reprint author), CZECHOSLOVAK ACAD SCI,FILOSOF USTAV,CS-11142 PRAGUE 1,CZECHOSLOVAKIA.
